head.title: Late Start Can't Stop A Chase For Gold

hedline.hl1: Late Start Can't Stop A Chase For Gold

abstract.p: Article on Costa Rican swimmer Claudia Poll preparing for Sydney Olympic Games (M)

block.p: The Olympic swimming star Claudia Poll and her longtime coach, Francisco Rivas, both laugh when they share memories of their early days together at a country club in Costa Rica. Poll, 7 years old at the time, was hardly the model student.

The Olympic swimming star Claudia Poll and her longtime coach, Francisco Rivas, both laugh when they share memories of their early days together at a country club in Costa Rica. Poll, 7 years old at the time, was hardly the model student.
''Claudia was not a good swimmer,'' Rivas said. ''She was slow, very slow. She would always come late to practice or not come at all.''
Twenty years later, Poll provides an explanation. ''I was having fun at that age,'' she said.

Poll is a little more serious these days. She is busy training for the Summer Games in Sydney, Australia, where she will try to retain the gold medal -- the first ever for Costa Rica -- that she won in the 200-meter freestyle in the 1996 Atlanta Games. So far, so good. During the Janet Evans Invitational this month in Los Angeles she established a meet record in the 200 meters at 1 minute 58.02 seconds. She also won the 400-meter freestyle in 4:09.04.

At 27, Poll is getting old for a world-class swimmer. Yet she remains as passionate about her sport as ever, which she largely attributes to her belated start; Poll did not get serious about swimming until she was 13 or 14.

''It was good not to push me at an early age,'' said Poll, who will also swim in the 4x100-meter freestyle at Sydney and may even enter the 800-meter competition. ''Many swimmers, when they begin at 8 or 9 years old, get bored when they're 15 or 16. I'm 27 and I still want to continue.''
No wonder. She has a whole nation behind her.
''People in Costa Rica love Claudia,'' Rivas said. ''She's more famous than the president.''

Her path to fame, however, has had its obstacles. First, she had to overcome the loss of her father, Bernado, an agricultural engineer who died of a heart attack when she was 10. Even today, the pain is not too far from the surface.
''When I swim, I always remember him,'' said Poll, tears quickly welling up in her eyes. ''Whether I swim well or swim poorly, I think he would be proud of me.''

Poll also had to deal with the inevitable comparisons with her older sister, Silvia, who preceded her to Olympic glory by winning the silver medal in the 200-meter freestyle at the 1988 Games in Seoul, South Korea, and was also coached by Rivas. Many younger siblings of great athletes falter under such pressure; Poll flourished.
''We had different careers with different expectations,'' she said.
Just to be safe, Rivas moved Poll along slowly so she would not have to compete against her sister, who is older by two and a half years.
''When Silvia was done, it was Claudia's time,'' he said.
Rivas and Claudia have formed a special relationship in their 20 years together.
''He's a father to me,'' she said.
At first, Rivas, who was close to Poll's father, corrected his student's interpretation. ''We're good friends,'' he said.
But when he was asked if she feels like a daughter to him, Rivas, who has two children of his own, took only the slightest pause and then smiled. ''Maybe,'' he said.
Their bond comes in handy when it becomes necessary to make adjustments in the middle of a meet. The Evans event was a perfect example.

During the preliminaries for the 400-meter competition, Rivas, armed as usual with his camcorder, noticed that Poll had gotten off to a poor start. When he first told her, she did not believe him. But, hours later, the two watched the videotape together at their hotel. Poll had no argument.

Rivas told Poll she needed to concentrate better, that, at this level, anybody could beat her. That night, nobody beat her. Her time in the final established a meet record. A day later, she won the 200-meter freestyle, breaking the meet record set by her sister.
With Sydney less than two months away, Poll is planning to train six hours a day, six days a week. The pressure, though, is not as intense this time.
''This is different from Atlanta,'' she said. ''I already have the gold medal.''
